awd_titl_txt: Generation of food-based chlorination disinfection byproducts (F-DBPs) during food processing
awd_abstract_narration:
With an estimated 76 million illnesses attributable to food per year in the US, rinsing produce with washwater containing high doses of chlorine disinfectant is becoming increasingly important. However, chlorine can react with biomolecules in the produce to form chlorinated byproducts that are potentially cancer-causing. This research will identify these chlorinated byproducts, focusing on those that remain in the produce until eaten by consumers. The research will quantify byproducts formed when lettuce, carrots, tomatoes, apples and chicken are treated with chlorine-containing washwater under conditions used in produce packing facilities.  Successful completion of this research will produce results that can be used to develop guidelines for chlorine doses that control foodborne illness while minimizing cancer risk. The results will also help maintain produce exports to countries concerned about these potentially cancer-causing byproducts in food.

Foodborne outbreaks linked to contaminated produce have heightened the importance of food disinfection in processing facilities. However, chlorine is known to react with organic matter to produce halogenated disinfection byproducts (DBPs) that are often toxic and even carcinogenic. Chlorinated DBP formation during food processing may be more significant than in drinking water, because food processing can involve 100-fold higher levels of both chlorine (~300 mg/L) and organic precursors.  While food safety currently focuses on pathogens, this benefit must be balanced with the potential health impacts of DBP formation. The goal of this research is to characterize DBPs produced in foods from reactions of chlorine with the amino acids tyrosine and tryptophan, and unsaturated fatty acids; two of the four major biomolecular groups in food which are highly reactive with chlorine. The central hypothesis of this research is that chlorination will initially form halogenated tyrosines, tryptophans, and fatty acid halohydrin biomolecules, and soluble byproducts can be released during prolonged chlorination. The shorter chlorine contact times of food washing (~15 min) compared to drinking water chlorination (days) will favor higher yields of these initial biomolecule-based byproducts relative to the soluble byproducts. The corollary to the central hypothesis is that biomolecule-based byproducts will remain in food while soluble byproducts will partition to the washwater. These will be tested by comparing the yields of soluble byproducts and initial biomolecule-based chlorination byproducts in various systems including: 1) model proteins and triglycerides, 2) lettuce, carrots, tomatoes, apples, and chickens treated under conditions relevant to food disinfection, and 3) samples collected from food washing facilities. The cytotoxic potencies of the amino acid- and fatty acid-based byproducts will be determined and used to normalize measured concentrations of these byproducts in foods for comparison to previous evaluations of DBP toxicity in drinking water. Benefits to society resulting from this research include broadening participation in STEM through support of the dissertation research of an African American graduate student, engagement of under-represented minority undergraduates through an REU program, and the involvement of a high school science teacher and underrepresented high school students in summer research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Chlorine is frequently applied as a chemical disinfectant within facilities that wash produce (e.g., lettuce) after harvest and to disinfect meats in slaughtering facilities. While chlorine helps control foodborne pathogens, it also reacts with the food to produce chlorinated byproducts that can be toxic.  Ultimately, food washing facilities will need to optimize chlorine exposures to control pathogens while minimizing the risks associated with long-term consumption of chlorinated byproducts.

The overall goal of this research was to identify chlorine-containing byproducts from chlorine reactions with the main biopolymers that are the target of reactions with chlorine disinfectants. The research identified major byproducts of chlorine reactions with the amino acids within proteins and with the fatty acids within lipids.  The research then demonstrated the increase in the concentrations of chlorotyrosines, a chlorinated byproduct of chlorine reactions with the amino acid tyrosine, and of oleic acid chlorohydrins, chlorinated byproducts formed from chlorine reactions with oleic acid in lipids. Levels of these byproducts increased significantly under chlorine exposure conditions used in food washing facilities.  While previous research has focused on low molecular weight compounds like chloroform that form as byproducts of food disinfection, these compounds are soluble and tend to remain in the washwater. In contrast, the byproducts we identified remain bound within the biopolymers within the vegetables and so are more relevant for consumers of the disinfected produce. We demonstrated that the toxicity associated with the levels of these compounds formed in ~1 forkfull of chlorine-disinfected broccoli was comparable to that for the chloroform and chloroacetic acid byproducts in 2 L of drinking water at their maximum permitted regulatory levels. 

Interestingly, we measured high levels of these byproducts in meats, even without chlorine disinfection, likely due to natural reactions with chlorine produced by enzymes within the living animals. Chlorine disinfection under conditions typically applied at meat processing facilities did not substantially increase the levels of these products above the background levels in these meats. The results indicating the occurrence of background levels of chlorinated byproducts in meats suggest another potential risk to a meat-based diet.

The project also demonstrated the occurrence of low levels of the same byproducts bound up in protein and lipid fragments in disinfected drinking waters and wastewaters reused as drinking water supplies.  Only a small fraction of the chlorinated byproducts in chlorinated drinking water has been identified. The research illustrates that the uncharacterized byproducts could be efficiently identified by predicting compounds that should form from chlorine reactions with the biopolymers from which all organic matter, including that it drinking water supplies, is constituted.  Although the specific compounds we identified were not drivers of toxicity in disinfected waters, the general approach of predicting byproducts can be applied to identify major constituents of the poorly characterized fraction of chlorinated byproducts.

The research served as the basis for the dissertation work of a PhD student who is now an assistant professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the University of Southern California.  Three post-doctoral researchers and one other PhD student also participated in this study.
